723411f-a.text:
1 to 6 State Street, (left), at. adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street, showing the Seamen's Church Institute (No. 11, corner building) and contiguous to it the house of the British Consulate General (No. 2). Also seen, are Nos. 46 to 34 Whitehall Street (right), west side, north from and including State, to Pearl Streets. Nos. 1 to 3 State and 46 to 40 Whitehall Streets, were demolished in 1913, and their sites are now (1937), occupied by the 12-story South Ferry Building. Nos. 4-5 (white house) and 6, upon which two additional stories were added, now comprise a
6-story annex to South Ferry Building.
723411f-a.folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY

723412f-a.text:
1 to 6 State Street, (left), at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of whitehall Street, showing the Seamen's Church Institute (No. 1, corner building) and contiguous to it the house of the British Consulate General (No. 2). Also seen, are Nos. 46 to 34 Whitehall Street,(right), west s ide, north from and including State to Pearl Streets. Nos. 1 to 3 State and 46 to 40 Chitehall Streets, were demolished in 1913 and this site is now (1937) occupiedNthe 12-story South Ferry Building. Nos. 4 and 5 (white house) and 5, upon which two additional stories were added, now comprise a 6-story annex
to the South Ferry Building.
1907.
Brown Brothers.
723412f-a.folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY

723410f-a.text:
Nots 1 to 5 State Street, at adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street (right). Dpon the latter thoroughfare appears a view to Pearl Street. The corner buildings comprising No's 1 to 3 State Street and 40 to 46 Whitehall Street were demolished in 1913. Upon this site was erected the 12-story South Ferry Building. No. 1 is occupied by the Seamen's Church Institute; No. 2, the British Consulate Weneral and No. 4, the Deutsches Lutheran Emigraten Haus (German Luthern Emigrant House).
1912
Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tieman Company
REPRODUCTION RIGRTS OUESTIORABLE
723410f-a.folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY

723419f-a.text:
7 State Street, north side, between Whitehall and earl Streets, showing the Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary, and the Home for Irish Immigrant Girls. This building was erected prior to 1800 and came into the possession of Moses Rogers about that time. William Bayard owned same subsequently. For a short while it was the property of Robert P. Getty, who became the first Mayor of Yonkers. Other occupants were, A. Gardener, and G. Howland (in 1830) after which it was used by the Federal Government during the Civil War for military purposes. The Pilot Commission were the last occupants prior to the purchase by the present tenents in 1885. A legend infers that the low brick addition beck of the Mission is the oldest slave building left. A descriptive account will be found in the column "About New York" by Meyer Berger. This appeared in the
New York Times of April 22, 1940.
723419f-a.folder: State Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY

723414f-a.text:
1 to 8 State Street (right to left) at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Whitehall Street, showing prominently the House for lIrish Immigrant Girls (Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary) at No. 7.
1922.
Eugene k. Armbruster Collection.
No 7 Stats Street was erected prior to 1800 and came into the possession of Moses Rogers about that time. William Bayard owned same subsequently. For a short while it was the property of Robert P. Getty, who became the first Mayor of Yonkers. Other ocoupants were A. Gardener, and G. Howland (in 1830), after which it was used by the Federal Gov't. during the Civil War for military purposes. The Pilot Commission were the last occupants prior to the pcrchase by the present tenents in 1885. A legend infers that the low brick addition back of the Mission is the oldest slave building left. A desoriptive account will be found in the column, "Vbout New York" by Meyer Berger. This appeared in the New York Times of April 22,1949,

716805f-a.text:
Bowling Green, south side, between State (right) and Whitehall (left) Streets. Building shown, is the U.S. Custom House; the front of which as shown, ocoupies the sites of Nos. 1-7 Bowling Green; former 4 1/2 story
buildings, known as Steamship Row..
January 144, 1932.
International News Fhotos.
